titleStmt.title: Reverend sir, having lately received from you, by the hands of my loving neighbour and friend Mris. Ducker, a booke undeserved and unexpected savour, one of your last books, intituled, Innocencie and Truth triumphing together I acknowledge it a just engagement of obliged gratitude, and therefore, accordingly, I doe here returne you deserved and most humble thankes for the same, by the same friendly hand. ...
titleStmt.author: Vicars, John, 1579 or 80-1652.

titleStmt.title: Reverend sir, having lately received from you, by the hands of my loving neighbour and friend Mris. Ducker, a booke undeserved and unexpected savour, one of your last books, intituled, Innocencie and Truth triumphing together I acknowledge it a just engagement of obliged gratitude, and therefore, accordingly, I doe here returne you deserved and most humble thankes for the same, by the same friendly hand. ...
titleStmt.author: Vicars, John, 1579 or 80-1652.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Michael Sparke Senior, at the Blew Bible in Greene Arbor,

notesStmt.note: Text ends on [Pi2r]; [Pi2v] reads: "To his Reverend and much respected good Friend, Mr. John Goodwin, be these I pray presented.".
Thomason catalogue: "containing strictures on John Goodwin's book 'Innocencie and Truth triumphing together'".
Annotation on Thomason copy [after date in colophon]: "1644".
Title from opening lines of tract.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p:
HAving lately received from you, by the hands of my loving Neighbour and Friend Mris. Ducker, a booke undeÅ¿erved and unexpected favour, one of your laÅ¿t bookes, intituled, Innocencie and Truth triumphing together; I acknowledge it a juÅ¿t engagement of obliged gratitude, and therefore, accordingly, I doe here returne you deÅ¿erved and moÅ¿t humble thankes for the Å¿ame, by the Å¿ame friendly hand. And becauÅ¿e (worthy Sir) I conceived and conÅ¿idered with my Å¿elfe, that you Å¿ent it by way of love and deÅ¿ire to give mee (who am, as I acknowledge, a poore and unworthy Presbyterian) Å¿atiÅ¿faction, if it might bee, touching your Independent Church-way: I having now peruÅ¿ed it all over, even Ã capite ad calcem (and I hope with that pietie and impartialitie, as my God hath enabled mee, which becomes a ChriÅ¿tian and fellow-Å¿ervant to the Å¿ame Lord JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t with you) I therefore hope you will, not Å¿o much pardon (which I pray not) as accept (which I heartily deÅ¿ire) with ChriÅ¿tian Candor, mine ingenuitie and plaine dealing with you, in now giving you an account, briefely, as I thought it moÅ¿t fit, of what light or content and Å¿atisfaction I have received from it. Truely Sir, I having read your EpiÅ¿tle to the Reader, found therein very full and faire promiÅ¿e of your ingenuous ayme and intention in the Å¿ubÅ¿equent diÅ¿courÅ¿e, viz. that you projected foure things therein, Brevitie, PerÅ¿picuitie, Moderation and Satisfaction. But having, I Å¿ay, puruÅ¿ed your Booke, truely Sir, (if I am not miÅ¿taken, as I beleeve I am not) you have come extreame Å¿hort of your promiÅ¿ed project, in every of the foure branches thereof. For firÅ¿t, if I found you Å¿hort, I am Å¿ure I found you Å¿harpe and tart; For PerÅ¿picuitie, I aÅ¿Å¿ure you I found much cloudie obÅ¿curitie; Veri Å¿imilitudinem multam, non ipÅ¿am veritatem; Å¿atisfaction, therefore none at all. But eÅ¿pecially, in that of projected moderation, and promiÅ¿ed temperature in writing, (the great defect, and foule fault, Å¿o cryed out upon by Independents againÅ¿t all Presbyterian Writers or Speakers) in Å¿tead of moderation I found abundance of bitterneÅ¿Å¿e and unÅ¿avory jerkes and jeers (the light iÅ¿Å¿ues, mee thought, rather of a youthfull green-head, than the Å¿olid expreÅ¿Å¿ions of a grave heart) Å¿prinkled, almoÅ¿t, over all your whole diÅ¿courÅ¿e; which I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, much troubled and affected mee with wonder to meet with, after Å¿uch a Å¿eeming promiÅ¿e of moderation: Some few of very many whereof (becauÅ¿e I knew, DoloÅ¿us verÅ¿atur in generalibus) I have here particularized with their pages where they are evidently and eaÅ¿ily to bee Å¿eene. As firÅ¿t, (to omit your Via Sanguinea, with all its moÅ¿t bitter and biting, yea Å¿orely wounding expoÅ¿itions of that terme, in your Theomachia, &c.) Pag. 13. you compare Mr. Prynne in his Reply, to the two falÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es, who falÅ¿ely accuÅ¿ed our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Saviour. And in the Å¿ame Page you tell the Reader, Here Mr. Prynne vapours in his Reply; and immediatly after, in the Å¿ame page how notably doe you jeere and Å¿coffe him about three Tabernacles? And with what an elated Å¿pirit doe you anÅ¿wer him, page 16. line 4. together with a downe-right jeere about a Nationall Church, Å¿ome 12. lines after? You alÅ¿o groÅ¿Å¿ely tax him with errors, Page 17. Sect. 21. And Page 18. and 19. you frequently jeere him, and among thoÅ¿e jeeres you tell him, that Acts 15. is onely Mr. Prynnes GoÅ¿pel; what a bitter and unchriÅ¿tian cenÅ¿ure lay you upon him, and all Presbyterians, Page 24. Sect. 26. towards the end of it? And Ã´ how you jeere him with his quotations, Page 37. towards the bottome; as alÅ¿o Page 49. and Page 51. you Å¿lander him with want of ReaÅ¿on and Truth too; and Page 52. you tell him, his pen Å¿pits black reproaches in the face of Independents. You alÅ¿o accuÅ¿e him (Page 65.) of much untruth; and the Å¿ame alÅ¿o againe moÅ¿t fouly, Page 84. Together with a Notable jeere, exalting your Å¿elfe, and vilifying Mr. Prynne, which I have noted at large in your booke, Page 85. Together with very many other Å¿uch like expreÅ¿Å¿ions, too tedious to bee here recited; And yet (Å¿trange to conÅ¿ider) you conclude them all (with the concluÅ¿ion of your booke) Page 99. in a hortatorie way to Mr. Prynne in theÅ¿e
words: That hee would put leÅ¿Å¿e Vinegar and Gall into his Inke, and more Wooll and Cotten. And in the ApoÅ¿tles words, EpheÅ¿. 4. 31. That all bitterneÅ¿Å¿e and evill Å¿peaking bee put away, as becomes Brethren. And now any impartiall perÅ¿on may judge whether you your Å¿elfe have followed this brotherly exhortation; Nay, whether contrariwiÅ¿e, you have not with unbrotherly aÅ¿perÅ¿ions, indeavoured to beÅ¿meare the face of that precious Gentleman, moÅ¿t worthy ever to bee honored both by you all and us all? Truely Sir, you Independent Gentlemen have dealt with this moÅ¿t worthy Å¿ervant of the Lord, juÅ¿t as the people of LyÅ¿tra did with the ApoÅ¿tle Paul, whom at firÅ¿t they Å¿o honored and admired, as that they were ready to deifie him and make him a God; but Å¿hortly after they furiouÅ¿ly indeavored to Å¿tone him to death: So yee, at the firÅ¿t, in the time of Mr. Prynnes firÅ¿t moÅ¿t elaborate and learned divine writings, yea and for his moÅ¿t glorious and Saint-like Å¿ufferings; O then, how yee all (with us) moÅ¿t highly (and that moÅ¿t juÅ¿tly too) honored him, and brought him home from baniÅ¿hment, as it were in the triumphing Chariot of your love and prayÅ¿es! But now, Å¿ince hee hath piouÅ¿ly and faithfully written againÅ¿t your Independent way, and onely for this, O how have you and almoÅ¿t all of your way, indeavored as much as in you is, to Å¿tone to death his illuÅ¿trious reputation, by moÅ¿t unworthy and unchriÅ¿tian reviling and vilipending of him, both in words and writings! Even him I Å¿ay, who for his pietie, humilitie, incomparable conÅ¿tancy, fortitude and magnanimitie in Å¿uffering for GoÅ¿pel Truths, was not inferiour to any of his moÅ¿t faithfull fellow-Å¿ufferers, yea, whoÅ¿e Å¿oundneÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿inceritie, whoÅ¿e profound learning and indefatigable labours in writing upon deepeÅ¿t points of Divinitie and controverted GoÅ¿pel Truths (witneÅ¿Å¿e his Perpetuitie of the eÅ¿tate of a regenerate man; his Anti-ArminianiÅ¿me, UnbiÅ¿hoping of Timothy and Titus, his HiÅ¿trio-MaÅ¿tix; and many other his later, moÅ¿t learned, orthodox and precious peeces) have made his never-dying name and fame moÅ¿t worthily renowned both in England and other parts of the world, beyond the Seas. And yet this noble Gentleman to bee thus, I Å¿ay, beÅ¿meared and beÅ¿pattred with your unjuÅ¿t accuÅ¿ations, onely I Å¿ay againe, for writing the Truth againÅ¿t Independent novelties; O! it is moÅ¿t Å¿ad and bad to conÅ¿ider. Truely Sir, you muÅ¿t here give mee leave to bee yet more plaine with you, I profeÅ¿Å¿e in the Å¿inceritie of my Å¿oule, that I doe moÅ¿t groundedly beleeve, that (had Mr. Prynne beene Å¿uch a Non-Å¿enÅ¿e, ConÅ¿cienceleÅ¿Å¿e, Irrationall, falÅ¿e and frivolous writer, as you and others of your way onely have Å¿trugled (but all in vaine) to make and demonÅ¿trate him by your laviÅ¿h tongues and pens) that yet, I Å¿ay certainly, Mr. John Goodwin was the moÅ¿t unfit man of all I know in London, to lay thoÅ¿e undeÅ¿erved criminations to Mr. Prynnes charge. For, you know good Sir, that Qui in alterum paratus eÅ¿t dicere, ipÅ¿um vitio carere oportet. For you therefore, Reverend Sir, to take upon you to tax Mr. Prynne of errours, untruths, and Å¿uch like, as you have done, it was Å¿urely moÅ¿t abÅ¿urd and unbeÅ¿eeming you: for it is too well knowne, how deepely you your Å¿elf (before ever this moÅ¿t unhappy and unholy difference of Independency with Presbytery was dream'd of) have beene cenÅ¿ured both of SocinianiÅ¿me; (and how juÅ¿tly too, others have moÅ¿t learnedly in publick declared) and more lately alÅ¿o how you have beene diÅ¿covered to hold a moÅ¿t dangerous, yea a moÅ¿t damnable opinion (as a learned Independent brother of yours termed it in my hearing, and who then Å¿aid hee would juÅ¿tifie it againÅ¿t you) touching juÅ¿tifying Faith by ChriÅ¿t. And now alÅ¿o, how fiercely you are fallen on this unhappily diÅ¿turbant new way of Independencie. I beÅ¿eech you therefore, Reverend Sir, Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to conÅ¿ider theÅ¿e things, to muÅ¿ter up your Å¿addeÅ¿t thoughts, and to Å¿ee into what a Labyrinth you are Å¿trangely and Å¿trongly intricated. Sir, I doe not, I cannot denie, but ingenuouÅ¿ly confeÅ¿Å¿e that God hath given you much learning and eminent parts, but truely Sir, if I bee not miÅ¿taken, I greatly feare, your Independent ProÅ¿elytes doe too much magnifie, if not (almoÅ¿t) deifie you for them, and as it was with Pythagoras his Scholars, an IpÅ¿e dixit is enough, I, feare for many, if not moÅ¿t of your diÅ¿ciples, jurare in verba MagiÅ¿tri; Whereby I pray God, your great parts and gifts bee not (thus) a great Snare to your Å¿oule, which I much feare, if not timely and truely Å¿eene into and prevented by Cordiall Å¿elfe-denyall, and holy humilitie in your
Å¿elfe, being more kindly affectioned with brotherly love, and in honour preferring others before your felfe, Rom. 12. 10. And thus (Reverend Sir) I have made humbly bold, by your owne occaÅ¿ion, lovingly, and (I hope) fairely and friendly as a poore true ChriÅ¿tian brother ought (Levit. 19. 17.) Liberare animam meam, and thus to manifeÅ¿t my reciprocall love and gratitude unto you, praying our good God it may bee accepted with the like right handed ChriÅ¿tian Candor, and Å¿implicitie of heart with which it is Å¿ent and intended; I humbly take my leave and reÅ¿t, Sir,

closer.signed: Yours in our great Lord and MaÅ¿ter. ChriÅ¿t JeÅ¿us, to be commanded. JOHN VICARS.

div.p: London Printed for Michael Sparke Senior, at the Blew Bible in Greene Arbor. 1645.
To his Reverend and much reÅ¿pected good Friend, Mr. John Goodwin, be theÅ¿e I pray preÅ¿ented.
